questions.answerB: About 50 percent
questions.answerC: About 70 percent
questions.answerD: About 95 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. The front brake supplies at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered protective clothing for a motorcyclist?
questions.answerB: Boots
questions.answerC: Gloves
questions.answerD: A stocking cap
questions.explanation: You should wear appropriate protective clothing when riding. Protective garments include sturdy pants and jackets that entirely cover your arms and legs, boots or heavy shoes that cover and support your ankles, and sturdy gloves.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat while riding and you must stop, it is usually best to:
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good tire.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good tire and steer to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes and stop quickly.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires fails, hold the handgrips firmly and begin to slow down by easing off the throttle while maintaining a straight course. If you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is still good, if you are sure of which tire that is. Edge toward the side of the road as you slow down, squeeze the clutch, and stop.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly than you would normally.
questions.answerB: Start slowing earlier than you would normally.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerD: Not communicate with the passenger while riding.
questions.explanation: Because of a passenger's additional weight, a motorcycle will respond more slowly with a passenger on board than with just one occupant. With a passenger, you should travel a bit more slowly than you normally would, start slowing sooner than you normally would, and increase your following distance. Always warn your passenger of any special conditions ahead.

questions.question: To be effective, an eye or face shield should be all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Resistant to penetration.
questions.answerC: Able to fasten securely.
questions.answerD: Airtight.
questions.explanation: To be effective, eye protection and face shields must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; give a clear view to either side; fasten securely; permit air to pass through; and permit enough room for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath.

questions.question: Motorcycle riders should choose footwear with soles that:
questions.answerA: Are made of hard, durable, slip-resistant material.
questions.answerB: Allow their feet to breathe.
questions.answerC: Have tall heels.
questions.answerD: Are made of soft, flimsy material.
questions.explanation: Choose riding boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Choose footwear with soles made of hard, durable, slip-resistant material.

questions.question: Where is the clutch lever located?
questions.answerB: Right handgrip
questions.answerC: Near the left foot peg
questions.answerD: Near the right foot peg
questions.explanation: The clutch lever of a motorcycle is generally located on the left handgrip. Be familiar with the locations of all controls before beginning to ride a motorcycle.

questions.question: Head and neck injuries can be reduced by:
questions.answerB: Wearing a leather jacket.
questions.answerC: Using the rear brake only.
questions.answerD: Wearing goggles.
questions.explanation: The risk of head and neck injuries is greatly reduced by wearing a high-quality helmet. A helmet is a rider's best defense against injury in the case of an accident.

questions.question: When passing parked cars, which part of the lane should you usually use?
questions.answerA: The left portion of the lane
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane
questions.answerD: Either the left or right portion of the lane
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, it is often safest to ride in the left portion of your lane. Riding in the left portion will keep you farthest from any opening car doors, people stepping out from between cars, and cars pulling out of parking spaces.

questions.question: If you wait an hour per alcoholic drink before you ride your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Your skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Side effects may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be fine as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, it is still possible for alcohol to accumulate in a person's system even if they consume only one drink per hour. This accumulation can still affect their ability to ride safely.

questions.question: When deciding on a lane position, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Always ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Be flexible and base your decision off of numerous factors.
questions.explanation: In general, there is no single best lane position. No portion of the lane need be avoided at all times. Position yourself in the portion of the lane where you are most likely to be seen and you can maintain a cushion of space around you.

questions.question: The clothing you wear while riding should protect you from all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Windburn.
questions.answerC: Chapped lips.
questions.answerD: Dehydration.
questions.explanation: The clothes you wear when riding a motorcycle should protect you from sunburn, windburn, rain, dehydration, cold, and parts of the motorcycle. Your clothing should provide you with additional protection in the case of a crash.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Either brake then swerve or swerve then brake.
questions.answerB: Brake and swerve at the same time.
questions.answerC: Choose to either brake or swerve.
questions.answerD: Not swerve and only use the front brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to brake and swerve to avoid a collision, you should take the actions separately. Do not brake while swerving because doing so may cause your motorcycle to fall over.

questions.question: Riding on the far side of a lane when following another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Is recommended because you will be seen easily.
questions.answerB: Is not recommended because drivers seldom use their side mirrors and may not see you.
questions.answerC: Is recommended because a passenger in the vehicle may tell the driver that you are there.
questions.answerD: Is illegal because you have to ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Most drivers do not look at their side mirrors as often as they look at their rearview mirror. Therefore, when following a car, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of the lane where you are most likely to be visible in the driver's rearview mirror.

questions.question: To prevent getting fatigued on a long ride, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Limit the distance traveled in a day.
questions.answerC: Take frequent rest breaks.
questions.answerD: Take artificial stimulants.
questions.explanation: To reduce the danger of fatigue when riding, dress to protect yourself against tiring weather conditions, such as wind and rain. Limit yourself to no more than about six hours of riding per day and stop for a break at least once every two hours. Avoid taking artificial stimulants since you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: A windshield:
questions.answerA: Is a good substitute for a face shield.
questions.answerB: Does not completely protect your eyes from the wind.
questions.answerC: Is required on all motorcycles.
questions.answerD: Should be used on windy days.
questions.explanation: A windshield is not an adequate substitute for the protection offered by goggles or a face shield. Most windshields will not protect your eyes from the wind.

questions.question: Making eye contact with other drivers:
questions.answerB: Guarantees that they will yield to you.
questions.answerC: Doesn’t mean that they see you.
questions.answerD: Is not worth the effort it takes.
questions.explanation: You should not rely on eye contact to guarantee that a driver will yield to you. It is not uncommon for a driver to look directly at a motorcyclist and still fail to actually notice them.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to blend into traffic and not be noticed by other drivers.
questions.answerB: Not use turn signals unless you are traveling at night.
questions.answerC: Use your turn signals when changing lanes and making turns.
questions.answerD: Ride closely to the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, ensure that you are visible to others on the road. Communicate your intentions through your turn signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain an adequate space cushion, scan your path of travel 12 seconds ahead of your vehicle, and be prepared to act if any hazards arise.

questions.question: When you are being passed, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Weave among the three portions of the lane as the vehicle passes.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally a good idea to ride in the center portion of your lane. Being on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases your risk of a collision. Being on the side farthest from the passing vehicle may prompt the other driver to merge back into your lane before it is safe.

questions.question: What does this signal mean?
questions.answerB: Slow down
questions.answerC: Speed up
questions.answerD: Exit
questions.explanation: Hand signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. This hand signal means "follow me."

questions.question: When being passed, do not move into the portion of the lane farthest from the passing vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The passing vehicle may re-enter your lane too early.
questions.answerB: You may prevent another vehicle from passing you.
questions.answerC: The portion of the lane nearest the passing vehicle is better.
questions.answerD: You are more likely to experience a wind blast from the passing vehicle on the far side of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, you should not ride on the side of your lane that is farthest from the passing vehicle. Doing so may tempt the driver to return to your lane before there is actually room for them to do so safely.

questions.question: It is important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerB: You will be slowing where other drivers won't expect it.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals are not working.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle brake lights are more difficult to see than the brake lights of larger vehicles, so flashing your brake light may help other drivers to notice it. You should flash you brake light before slowing down where other drivers may not expect you to slow down, such as in the middle of a block or when approaching an alley.

questions.question: A three-wheeled motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Handles curves about the same as a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Handles curves differently than a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Should not be operated in curves.
questions.answerD: Should use the shoulder when taking a curve.
questions.explanation: The cornering characteristics of a three-wheeled motorcycle or a motorcycle with a sidecar differ from those of a two-wheeled motorcycle.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection usually takes:
questions.answerA: A few minutes and should be done no more than once a month.
questions.answerB: A few minutes and should be done before every ride.
questions.answerC: Over an hour and should be performed by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Over an hour and must only be done if you will be carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection before every ride. It should usually take only a few minutes.

questions.question: What can help reduce the risk of a head or neck injury in the event of a crash?
questions.answerB: Riding under the speed limit
questions.answerC: Wearing a helmet
questions.answerD: Not allowing a passenger on the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Wearing a helmet is the single most effective thing you can do to reduce the risk of head or neck injuries in the event of a crash.

questions.question: A properly-fitted motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows the rider to touch the ground with their feet while seated.
questions.answerB: Has a seat even with the rider's waist.
questions.answerC: Has a seat that is 10 inches above the rider's waist.
questions.answerD: Has a seat that is 10 inches below the rider's waist.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle fits you properly, your feet should be able to reach the ground while you are seated. When riding your motorcycle, keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: Before changing lanes, motorcycle riders should turn their heads to look over their shoulders because:
questions.answerA: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like other vehicles.
questions.answerB: They can catch the attention of other drivers by turning their heads.
questions.answerC: Mirrors are not really helpful.
questions.answerD: They should try to make eye contact with surrounding drivers.
questions.explanation: Like any other vehicle, a motorcycle has blind spots that cannot be seen by a rider using their mirrors. A motorcyclist should always turn their head to check for vehicles or other hazards in their blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: When it starts to rain, it is usually best to:
questions.answerB: Exit the road.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.explanation: The center of a lane can be especially hazardous when wet. When it begins to rain, avoid the center of the road by riding in the tire tracks left by cars. The left tire track is often the best option.

questions.question: Smoothly downshifting on motorcycles:
questions.answerB: Can allow the rider to engine brake.
questions.answerC: Is illegal.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if other vehicles are around.
questions.explanation: Engine braking by smoothly downshifting can be a useful option for motorcyclists. If you choose to engine brake, apply your brake lights separately to let other drivers know that you are slowing down.

questions.question: Motorists entering a highway from an entrance ramp to your right may not see your motorcycle. To help the entering drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Flash your lights.
questions.answerC: Move to the left portion of your lane so they can share the lane, if necessary.
questions.answerD: Move into another lane, if necessary.
questions.explanation: Give plenty of room to vehicles merging onto a highway from an entrance ramp. Merge into a lane farther away from the entrance ramp, if necessary. If it is not possible to change lanes, adjust your speed to allow room for the vehicle to safely enter the highway.

questions.question: To be effective, a face shield should not:
questions.answerB: Allow clear views to both sides.
questions.answerC: Be airtight.
questions.answerD: Fasten securely.
questions.explanation: An effective face shield should be free of scratches, be resistant to penetration, allow clear views to both sides, fasten securely, permit air to pass through, and provide enough space for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath. It is important for a face shield to permit the passage of air because an airtight face shield can create fogging and make it difficult for a rider to see.

questions.question: Riding at night:
questions.answerB: Is made safer by wearing reflective clothing.
questions.answerC: Is not safe because other drivers cannot see your turn signals.
questions.answerD: Should only be done in the city.
questions.explanation: You should wear reflective materials when riding at night to make yourself more visible to other road users.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride slower than the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.explanation: To help reduce your reaction time, you should cover the clutch and brakes. This is especially helpful when riding through areas where potential hazards are likely.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should:
questions.answerB: Take more than an hour.
questions.answerC: Be complicated to perform.
questions.answerD: Not be done before every ride.
questions.explanation: It is important to do a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This will usually take you only a few minutes.

questions.question: Increase your following distance if:
questions.answerB: Riding conditions are normal.
questions.answerC: The roadway is wet.
questions.answerD: You can see through the vehicle in front of you.
questions.explanation: Open up your following distance if your motorcycle will require a longer distance than normal to stop. Additionally, if you are riding in heavy traffic or if you cannot see through the vehicle in front of you, you should also increase your following distance.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers see you, especially if they make eye contact.
questions.answerB: Never assume other drivers see you.
questions.answerC: Stay focused on moving through the intersection.
questions.answerD: Speed up to make others notice you.
questions.explanation: Never assume that other drivers see you, even if they make eye contact with you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist and still fail to notice them. Always reduce your speed when approaching an intersection.

questions.question: Motorcycle headlights are:
questions.answerA: Usually more powerful than a car’s headlights.
questions.answerB: Usually just as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerC: Usually not as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerD: Usually larger than a car’s headlights.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle headlights are generally smaller and less powerful than those of cars.

questions.question: A face shield:
questions.answerA: Provides protection for the eyes and face.
questions.answerB: Is not recommended.
questions.answerC: Is required.
questions.answerD: Does not protect the face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, impact-resistant face shield provides the greatest degree of protection for a wearer's eyes and face. Eyeglasses or sunglasses are not an adequate substitute. In Vermont, you are not legally required to wear eye or face protection if your motorcycle has a windshield, though it is recommended.

questions.question: Before carrying a passenger in traffic for the first time, you should:
questions.answerB: Practice riding on an empty road.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights so others can see you.
questions.answerD: Practice riding on the shoulder of a road.
questions.explanation: Before transporting a passenger or heavy load in traffic for the first time, practice riding on a quiet road to get used to how your motorcycle handles differently with the additional weight.

questions.question: If the road is wet, you should avoid:
questions.answerA: The left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: All areas of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks collect in a strip in the center portion of a lane. This strip usually still provides enough traction for motorcyclists to operate safely, except when the road is wet. The strip is usually narrow enough that you can ride to its side and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Many over-the-counter drugs:
questions.answerB: Decrease the danger of riding.
questions.answerC: Only affect your riding if you drink along with taking the medication.
questions.answerD: Have the same effect on everyone.
questions.explanation: Like alcohol, many other drugs (including prescription medications, over-the-counter medications, and illegal drugs) have side effects that may impair your ability to ride safely.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a safe step in preventing fatigue while riding?
questions.answerB: Taking artificial stimulants
questions.answerC: Limiting the distance ridden in one day
questions.answerD: Taking frequent breaks
questions.explanation: When taking a long trip, be sure to schedule in frequent breaks to rest and try not to ride more than six hours in one day. Wind, cold, and rain can make you tire quickly, so be sure to dress to protect yourself from the elements. Avoid taking artificial stimulants, as the effects when they wear off can be very dangerous.

questions.question: When looking through a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn both your head and your shoulders to get a better look.
questions.answerB: Turn just your head, not your shoulders.
questions.answerC: Use only your mirrors.
questions.answerD: Only move your eyes, not your head.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: What should a motorcyclist do to prevent possible injury when riding on a slippery surface?
questions.answerB: Reduce their speed.
questions.answerC: Make sudden moves.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When riding on a slippery surface, it is safest to decrease your speed. Making sudden moves on a slippery surface could cause your motorcycle to skid. Do not travel on the shoulder to escape a slippery road.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors, you should focus on:
questions.answerA: The road behind and to the side of your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Your arms.
questions.answerC: The road in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: The side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you. When properly adjusted, a mirror may show the edge of your arm or shoulder, but it’s the road behind you and to the side of you that is most important.

questions.question: The front brake is:
questions.answerB: Safe, even if used improperly.
questions.answerC: Only to be used if the rear brake fails.
questions.answerD: Not to be used regularly.
questions.explanation: The front brake is safe to use as long as it is used properly. The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake, providing at least three-fourths of the total stopping power.

questions.question: When riding through a curve, a group of motorcyclists should:
questions.answerB: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerC: Ride in a side-by-side formation.
questions.answerD: Use both lanes if possible.
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is generally recommended, riders in a group should move into a single-file formation when taking curves, taking turns, entering a highway, or leaving a highway.

questions.question: When making a turn:
questions.answerA: There is less traction available for stopping.
questions.answerB: There is more traction available for stopping.
questions.answerC: Stopping is no different than making a stop on a straightaway.
questions.answerD: Stopping should never be attempted.
questions.explanation: It is possible to brake while turning, but it should be done with great care. When a motorcycle is leaning to turn, there is less traction available for stopping because some of the traction is being used for turning.

questions.question: When stopping, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Grab at the front brake lever.
questions.answerB: Keep your knees against the gas tank and keep your eyes up.
questions.answerC: Apply increasing pressure to the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the front brake.
questions.explanation: For maximum straight-line braking, you should apply the brakes smoothly and firmly. As more weight transfers forward, more will be more traction available at the front wheel, allowing you to apply the front brake with progressively increasing force while reducing the pressure being used on the rear brake. Keep your knees against the gas tank and your eyes up to help keep yourself moving in a straight line.

questions.question: Where is the clutch lever located?
questions.answerB: Right handgrip
questions.answerC: Near the left foot peg
questions.answerD: Near the right foot peg
questions.explanation: The clutch lever of a motorcycle is generally located on the left handgrip. Be familiar with the locations of all controls before beginning to ride a motorcycle.

questions.question: Under normal conditions, maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerB: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should maintain a following distance of at least two seconds. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: If you are riding in traffic when a small animal enters your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Do whatever you can, including swerving into other lanes, to avoid hitting the animal.
questions.answerB: Switch lanes as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane.
questions.answerD: Flash your lights to try to scare the animal.
questions.explanation: Do everything you safely can to avoid hitting an animal in the road. If you are in traffic, however, you should remain in your lane. Swerving into another lane of traffic to avoid hitting an animal can cause you to collide with another driver. Hitting something small is less dangerous than hitting something big.

questions.question: Intersections are usually:
questions.answerA: Safe since there is so much traffic there.
questions.answerB: A dangerous spot for riders.
questions.answerC: Difficult to figure out.
questions.answerD: Safer than the open road.
questions.explanation: Intersections can be dangerous because they present the greatest degree of potential conflict between motorcyclists and other drivers.

questions.question: An approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Allows the wearer to see as far to the sides as necessary.
questions.answerB: Restricts the field of vision.
questions.answerC: Is usually uncomfortable.
questions.answerD: Does not have any markings or tags.
questions.explanation: Any approved helmet will allow a rider to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding. Approved helmets will have labels and markings providing the manufacturer's name, relevant information and instructions, and information about the standards the helmet meets.

questions.question: Fatigue can be increased by:
questions.answerB: Riding in cool weather.
questions.answerC: Being comfortable during your ride.
questions.answerD: Starting a ride late in the day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the danger of fatigue when riding, dress to protect yourself against tiring weather conditions, such as wind and rain. Limit yourself to no more than about six hours of riding per day and stop for a break at least once every two hours. Avoid taking artificial stimulants since you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: If wearing footwear with laces, the laces:
questions.answerB: Should hang loose.
questions.answerC: Should be taken off of the footwear.
questions.answerD: Should be glued together.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should securely tuck in the laces of your footwear so that they will not catch on your motorcycle.

questions.question: If you must ride over an obstacle in the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Approach it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible.
questions.answerB: Try to hit only the side of the obstacle.
questions.answerC: Speed up before contacting the obstacle.
questions.answerD: Lean the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid riding over an obstacle, you should approach it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down, make sure your motorcycle is straight, rise slightly off of your seat, and roll on the throttle just before contact.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: Always look through a turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head to look, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger on a motorcycle, you must:
questions.answerA: Have a seat that is large enough for two riders.
questions.answerB: Only have one set of footrests.
questions.answerC: Not encourage the passenger to wear protective clothing.
questions.answerD: Put a sticker on the brake light to warn other motorists that a passenger is on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: You should not carry a passenger unless your motorcycle has a seat that is large enough for two riders. The motorcycle should be equipped with footrests for the passenger. Your passenger should wear the same kind of protective gear that is recommended to operators.

questions.question: If riding a three-wheel motorcycle in a group, you should travel in a:
questions.answerB: Pyramid formation.
questions.answerC: Single-file line.
questions.answerD: Row of pairs.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is usually best for a group of two-wheeled motorcycles, three-wheeled motorcycles are too wide to allow this formation. A group of riders on three-wheeled motorcycles should travel in a single-file line.

questions.question: If either tire goes flat while riding, you should:
questions.answerB: Hold the handle grips loosely.
questions.answerC: Gently apply the brake of the non-flat tire.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to exit the road more quickly.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires goes flat while you are riding, you should ease off the throttle and maintain a straight course as you slow down. If you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is not flat, if you are certain of which tire that is.

questions.question: A person with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerB: 0.04 percent
questions.answerC: 0.08 percent
questions.answerD: 0.1 percent
questions.explanation: In the state of Kentucky, a person with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent is considered legally intoxicated. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, clothing:
questions.answerA: Should be loose enough to flap in the wind.
questions.answerB: Should not cover your arms or legs completely.
questions.answerC: Should not include a jacket if the weather is warm.
questions.answerD: Can provide protection in the event of a crash.
questions.explanation: The right clothing can provide vital protection if you are involved in a collision. Always wear a jacket and pants that fully cover your arms and legs, even in warm weather. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but should also be loose enough that your movement is not restricted.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: You must complete the pass without exceeding the speed limit.
questions.answerB: You may complete the pass in a no passing zone if the pass was started before the no passing zone began.
questions.answerC: You may exceed the speed limit.
questions.answerD: You should pass on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: All passes must be completed within the posted speed limits and only in areas where passing is permitted.

questions.question: A motorcyclist is well-protected if they are wearing:
questions.answerA: A jacket that allows the arms to be exposed.
questions.answerB: Boots with tall heels.
questions.answerC: Leather gloves.
questions.answerD: Shoes that stop below their ankle.
questions.explanation: For your protection while riding, it is best to wear a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs completely. Boots or shoes should be tall and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Footwear should have low heels that will not catch on the foot pegs or rough road surfaces. Gloves made of leather or another durable material will help protect your hands in the event of a crash while providing you with an improved grip on the controls.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, you should look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: A major effect of alcohol consumption is:
questions.answerB: The slowing down of bodily functions.
questions.answerC: Increasing nervousness.
questions.answerD: Increasing alertness.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant. It slows down and impairs bodily functions, both physical and mental.

questions.question: Maintain an adequate following distance behind other vehicles:
questions.answerA: To allow you time and space to identify and react to hazards.
questions.answerB: So you can tailgate.
questions.answerC: To allow for traffic counters to accurately count you as a vehicle.
questions.answerD: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.explanation: Maintaining an adequate following distance ensures that you will have enough space to stop or swerve out of the way if the vehicle ahead of you stops suddenly. A space cushion also provides you with a better view of any hazards on the road surface, such as potholes.

questions.question: When both braking and swerving must be done to avoid an unexpected hazard, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Perform one action, then the other.
questions.answerB: Perform both actions at the same time and apply extra braking pressure.
questions.answerC: Perform both actions at the same time, but mainly focus on swerving.
questions.answerD: Not perform either action.
questions.explanation: Because you need adequate traction to swerve safely, you should not brake and swerve at the same time. Instead, if you approach a hazard that requires you to brake and swerve, you should perform one action and then the other.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Either brake then swerve or swerve then brake.
questions.answerB: Brake and swerve at the same time.
questions.answerC: Choose to either brake or swerve.
questions.answerD: Not swerve and only use the front brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to brake and swerve to avoid a collision, you should take the actions separately. Do not brake while swerving because doing so may cause your motorcycle to fall over.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should tell them to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as they can without crowding you.
questions.answerC: Hold firmly onto your waist, hips, or belt.
questions.answerD: Feel free to talk whenever they want.
questions.explanation: To help keep the operator focused on riding, passengers should avoid unnecessary conversation or movement. Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator and hold firmly onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: In a slow, tight turn, the rider should:
questions.answerA: Counterbalance the leaning motorcycle by keeping their body upright.
questions.answerB: Lean at the same angle as the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Lean in the opposite direction of the motorcycle and the turn.
questions.answerD: Counterbalance their leaning body by keeping the motorcycle upright.
questions.explanation: When taking normal turns, lean at the same angle as your motorcycle. However, in slow, tight turns, you should counterbalance the leaning motorcycle by keeping your body upright.

questions.question: When conducting a pre-ride check, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The brakes make a loud squeaking noise.
questions.answerB: The brakes cause some friction with the steering.
questions.answerC: Each brake can hold the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Only the rear brake can hold the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Check your brake levers individually before every ride. Make sure each one feels firm and holds the motorcycle when the brake is fully applied.

questions.question: Which of the following is a good color to wear to be seen?
questions.answerB: Black
questions.answerC: Brown
questions.answerD: Deep blue
questions.explanation: Orange, red, yellow, or green clothing can make you easier to see while riding a motorcycle. Wear brightly-colored clothing no matter what time of day you are riding.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should be placed:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerB: Just behind the lead rider.
questions.answerC: At the back of the group.
questions.answerD: Anywhere within the group.
questions.explanation: Inexperienced riders should ride near the front of a group, just behind the leader, so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind.

questions.question: Riding at night:
questions.answerB: Is made safer by wearing reflective clothing.
questions.answerC: Is not safe because other drivers cannot see your turn signals.
questions.answerD: Should only be done in the city.
questions.explanation: You should wear reflective materials when riding at night to make yourself more visible to other road users.

questions.question: One of the benefits of performing regular maintenance on your motorcycle is that:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle will ride well for a long period of time.
questions.answerB: The maintenance check will take a lot of time.
questions.answerC: Maintenance will be costly.
questions.answerD: Maintenance checks can often prevent parking tickets.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle will continue to ride like new if it is properly maintained and routine inspections become a part of its regular maintenance cycle.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to wobble, you should:
questions.answerB: Use the brakes gradually.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Trying to accelerate out of a wobble is dangerous and will only make your motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly (without trying to fight the wobble), gradually close the throttle to slow down, and move your weight as far forward and downward as possible. Pull off the road as soon as you can.

questions.question: If using a sidecar to transport a load, you should:
questions.answerA: Allow the load to move freely.
questions.answerB: Secure the load so its weight does not shift.
questions.answerC: Place the load unsecured in the seat.
questions.answerD: Secure the load near the front of the sidecar.
questions.explanation: Loads carried in a sidecar should be secured so that they do not shift and affect the motorcycle's handling. Loads should be distributed toward the rear of the sidecar to reduce tipping of the nose of the sidecar in the event of a sudden left turn.

questions.question: When applying the front brake, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the lever by squeezing firmly and progressively.
questions.answerB: Grab at the brake with only two fingers.
questions.answerC: Press down on the brake lever with your foot.
questions.answerD: Stomp on the brake lever.
questions.explanation: To apply the front brake, firmly and smoothly squeeze the brake lever with all four fingers, applying progressively more force.

questions.question: When riding downhill on a motorcycle with a sidecar:
questions.answerA: Stopping will be easier than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerB: Stopping will take longer than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerC: You cannot stop.
questions.answerD: Stopping is about as easy as it is when riding without the sidecar.
questions.explanation: Riding with a sidecar increases the weight of a motorcycle and increases the braking force needed to stop the motorcycle. Slowing and stopping take longer when riding a vehicle downhill than when riding on a flat surface.

questions.question: When adjusting your rearview mirror, be sure you can:
questions.answerA: See the lane behind you and the lane next to you.
questions.answerB: See only the lane behind you.
questions.answerC: See only the lane next to you.
questions.answerD: See most of your helmet.
questions.explanation: Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you. When properly adjusted, a mirror may show the edge of your arm or shoulder, but it’s the road behind you and to the side of you that is most important.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerB: Keep your intentions unknown from other drivers.
questions.answerC: Always stay within a foot of another vehicle.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: To help provide space for drivers attempting to merge into your lane from an entrance ramp, you should:
questions.answerB: Merge into the next lane, if possible.
questions.answerC: Not worry about it, since they are the ones trying to merge.
questions.answerD: Ride on the far left shoulder.
questions.explanation: Drivers merging onto a highway and into your lane may not notice your motorcycle. Give them plenty of space to safely merge by moving into a different lane, if you can.

questions.question: When being passed, do not move into the portion of the lane farthest from the passing vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The passing vehicle may re-enter your lane too early.
questions.answerB: You may prevent another vehicle from passing you.
questions.answerC: The portion of the lane nearest the passing vehicle is better.
questions.answerD: You are more likely to experience a wind blast from the passing vehicle on the far side of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, you should not ride on the side of your lane that is farthest from the passing vehicle. Doing so may tempt the driver to return to your lane before there is actually room for them to do so safely.

questions.question: Waiting for one hour to ride after having one drink:
questions.answerA: Guarantees that you cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Guarantees that your riding skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Should be fine as long as you ride slowly.
questions.answerD: May not entirely remove the effects of alcohol from your body.
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. The amount of time required to lower a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) can vary, so it is safest not to operate a motor vehicle after consuming any amount of alcohol.

questions.question: If the road is wet, you should avoid:
questions.answerA: The left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: All areas of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks collect in a strip in the center portion of a lane. This strip usually still provides enough traction for motorcyclists to operate safely, except when the road is wet. The strip is usually narrow enough that you can ride to its side and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: When going through a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stay in the same portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerB: Always stay in the left portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerC: Always stay in the right portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerD: Remember that the best path may not follow the curve of the road.
questions.explanation: Road and traffic conditions can change at any time. Always be prepared to change your lane position as appropriate no matter where you are on a roadway. The best path through a curve does not necessarily follow the curve of the road.

questions.question: The clothing you wear while riding should protect you from all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Windburn.
questions.answerC: Chapped lips.
questions.answerD: Dehydration.
questions.explanation: The clothes you wear when riding a motorcycle should protect you from sunburn, windburn, rain, dehydration, cold, and parts of the motorcycle. Your clothing should provide you with additional protection in the case of a crash.

questions.question: If you think stopping your motorcycle will take longer than usual, you should:
questions.answerB: Shorten your following distance.
questions.answerC: Leave the road.
questions.answerD: Speed up.
questions.explanation: Lengthen your following distance when traveling on a slippery surface. If it will take longer than usual for your motorcycle to stop, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: Your lane position should help you:
questions.answerA: Communicate your intentions to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Keep others from passing you.
questions.answerC: Travel to your destination as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Linger in the blind spots of other drivers.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should protect your lane from other drivers while communicating your intentions to them.

questions.question: If your front wheel begins to skid, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the front brake engaged and ride out the skid.
questions.answerB: Keep the front brake engaged and release the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Immediately release and re-engage the front brake.
questions.answerD: Release the front brake and increase the pressure on the rear brake.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks while braking, you should release the front brake immediately and completely before re-applying it smoothly.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to wobble, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep riding, as the wobble will likely correct itself.
questions.answerB: Quickly brake.
questions.answerC: Close the throttle to slow down.
questions.answerD: Accelerate quickly.
questions.explanation: Trying to accelerate out of a wobble will only increase the problem. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down while gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as you can, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Once off the road, you should address the problem causing the wobble.

questions.question: When riding at night, a motorcyclist should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerB: Three seconds.
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.answerD: Five seconds.
questions.explanation: Because it is more difficult to see and judge distances in the dark than in daylight, you should maintain an expanded following distance of at least three seconds when riding at night. It may take you longer than usual to realize the vehicle in front of you has stopped and you may need additional time to slow or stop to avoid hitting the vehicle.

questions.question: Motorcycle headlights are:
questions.answerA: Usually more powerful than a car’s headlights.
questions.answerB: Usually just as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerC: Usually not as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerD: Usually larger than a car’s headlights.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle headlights are generally smaller and less powerful than those of cars.

questions.question: When you are being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in any portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind, stay in the center portion of your lane. This will discourage the other driver from re-entering your lane before it is safe.

questions.question: Hearing protection is:
questions.answerA: Not needed if you wear a helmet.
questions.answerB: Needed in addition to a helmet.
questions.answerC: Only needed on windy days.
questions.answerD: Not needed if you are carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Exposure to engine and wind noise can damage your hearing, even if you are wearing a helmet. Hearing protection can guard against this while still allowing you to hear essential sounds like horns and sirens.

questions.question: You should completely check your motorcycle:
questions.answerB: Once a week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a year.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle requires more frequent attention than a car. Make a complete check of your motorcycle before every ride.

questions.question: When you have mounted your motorcycle, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Make sure the mirrors are clean.
questions.answerB: Make sure the horn works.
questions.answerC: Close the fuel supply valve.
questions.answerD: Make sure the clutch works smoothly.
questions.explanation: After mounting your motorcycle, you should make sure the clutch, throttle, horn, and brakes all work properly. Clean and adjust the mirrors and make sure that the fuel supply valve is open.

questions.question: To be effective, an eye or face shield must:
questions.answerB: Prevent air from passing through.
questions.answerC: Not allow for eyeglasses to fit underneath.
questions.answerD: Restrict your vision to the sides.
questions.explanation: To be effective, an eye or face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through to prevent fogging; and allow room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: If you are being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles often seem to attract dogs. If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind.

questions.question: When consuming alcohol:
questions.answerA: The body is largely unaffected until the point of legal intoxication.
questions.answerB: The body may experience some negative effects, but they are usually minimal until the point of legal intoxication.
questions.answerC: Driving and riding abilities are affected long before the point of legal intoxication.
questions.answerD: There is nothing to be concerned about if consuming only a drink or two.
questions.explanation: When someone consumes alcohol, impairment of driving and riding abilities begins well below the legal limit for intoxication. Even a single drink can cause significant impairment.

questions.question: If you are unable to avoid hitting an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerB: Slow down before contact.
questions.answerC: Lean the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Stay seated on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid hitting an obstacle in the roadway, you should try to hit it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can before contact, keep your motorcycle upright, rise slightly off of your seat, and roll the throttle slightly to lighten the front end just before impact.

questions.question: To make a quick stop on wet pavement, you should:
questions.answerB: Use only the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.explanation: Use both brakes if you must make a quick stop on a slippery surface. The front brake is safe to use on a slippery surface if applied gradually to prevent locking.

questions.question: Keep an expanded cushion of space between your motorcycle and the vehicle in front of you:
questions.answerA: When conditions will make stopping more difficult than usual.
questions.answerB: When you want to look at the scenery.
questions.answerC: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.answerD: To prevent the driver in front of you from knowing you are there.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the motorcycle is as easy to see as other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Assume other drivers can’t see you.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with taking steps to ensure that other drivers see you.
questions.answerD: Ride offensively.
questions.explanation: Because motorcycles are small in stature and have fewer and smaller lights than other vehicles, they can be difficult to see. For your safety, it is best to ride defensively and assume that others on the road do not see you.

questions.question: A motorcycle operator can slow down by:
questions.answerB: Upshfting.
questions.answerC: Cross-shifting.
questions.answerD: Rolling on the throttle.
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists often slow down by simply downshifting. Motorcyclists should be aware that slowing down in this manner does not activate the brake lights.

questions.question: You should check your tires for all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Tread.
questions.answerC: General wear.
questions.answerD: Flexibility.
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle, you should check the air pressure, general wear, and tread of your tires.

questions.question: If you accidentally lock your rear wheel while braking on a good traction surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep it locked until you come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Release the rear brake and only use the front brake.
questions.answerC: Release the rear brake, then quickly re-apply it.
questions.answerD: Release the rear brake and down shift.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock the rear brake on a good traction surface, keep it locked until you have completely stopped. Even with a locked rear wheel, you should still be able to control your motorcycle if it is upright and traveling in a straight line.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerB: Never come into contact with the operator.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back on their seat as possible.
questions.answerD: Hold onto their seat.
questions.explanation: Before riding while carrying a passenger, you should instruct your passenger to lean with you through turns and curves. They should hold onto your waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerB: Hold onto their seat.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back on the bike as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto the operator.
questions.explanation: Passengers should sit directly behind the operator and lean as the operator leans. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator, holding onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: To be effective, a face shield should not:
questions.answerB: Allow clear views to both sides.
questions.answerC: Be airtight.
questions.answerD: Fasten securely.
questions.explanation: An effective face shield should be free of scratches, be resistant to penetration, allow clear views to both sides, fasten securely, permit air to pass through, and provide enough space for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath. It is important for a face shield to permit the passage of air because an airtight face shield can create fogging and make it difficult for a rider to see.

questions.question: When passing parked vehicles, motorcycle riders should be especially cautious of:
questions.answerA: Motorists looking for a place to park.
questions.answerB: Cars leaving their parking spaces.
questions.answerC: Oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Noise.
questions.explanation: When passing parked vehicles, use caution. You may encounter vehicles pulling away from the curb or leaving parking spaces.

questions.question: To swerve correctly, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn the handlebars quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handle grip in the direction you plan to swerve.
questions.answerD: Press the handle grip in the direction opposite of where you plan to swerve.
questions.explanation: If you must swerve to avoid a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the appropriate handle grip. To swerve to the left, press the left handle grip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handle grip, then the left.

questions.question: Which of the following should you inspect during a pre-ride check?
questions.answerA: The general wear and tread of your tires
questions.answerB: The amount of cushion your seat has
questions.answerC: The shine of your paint
questions.answerD: The wind direction
questions.explanation: Before setting off on any ride, you should do a thorough check of your motorcycle. Inspect the tires, oil and fluid levels, headlight, tail light, turn signals, brake light, clutch and throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Equip and adjust your motorcycle to carry the passenger.
questions.answerB: Ride as you would without a passenger.
questions.answerC: Ensure that footrests are available for only you, the operator.
questions.answerD: Instruct the passenger after you begin your trip.
questions.explanation: You should transport a passenger only if your motorcycle is appropriately equipped and adjusted to do so. Among other things, your motorcycle should have separate footrests for the passenger and a seat that is large enough for more than one person to sit comfortably. You may need to adjust your headlight, tire pressure, and suspension to accommodate the extra weight of a passenger.

questions.question: To adjust for added weight when riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Operate at a slower speed than usual.
questions.answerB: Maintain a shorter following distance that you would if riding without a passenger.
questions.answerC: Operate at a faster speed than usual.
questions.answerD: Brake a little later than you would if riding without a passenger.
questions.explanation: The extra weight of a passenger means that your motorcycle will need more time than usual to speed up, slow down, and turn. To accommodate the added weight, you should reduce your speed; start slowing earlier than normal; increase your following distance; and seek out larger gaps when crossing, entering, or merging with traffic.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked cars, a motorcycle operator should be prepared for:
questions.answerB: A motorist to unexpectedly pull out of a parking space and into traffic.
questions.answerC: Parking meters.
questions.answerD: Other motorists to see the motorcycle and stay out of its way.
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, a motorcyclist should be prepared for a parked car to suddenly pull out of a parking space and into traffic. It is often safest for a motorcyclist to ride in the left portion of their lane when passing a row of parked cars on their right to create the most possible space between their motorcycle and any potential hazards.

questions.question: At a minimum, how often should a motorcycle's hydraulic fluid be checked?
questions.answerB: Once a week
questions.answerC: Once a year
questions.answerD: Before every ride
questions.explanation: Pre-ride motorcycle inspections are an important part of ensuring safe riding. Hydraulic fluids and coolants should be checked at least once a week.

questions.question: Riding on the far side of a lane when following another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Is recommended because you will be seen easily.
questions.answerB: Is not recommended because drivers seldom use their side mirrors and may not see you.
questions.answerC: Is recommended because a passenger in the vehicle may tell the driver that you are there.
questions.answerD: Is illegal because you have to ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Most drivers do not look at their side mirrors as often as they look at their rearview mirror. Therefore, when following a car, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of the lane where you are most likely to be visible in the driver's rearview mirror.

questions.question: When approaching a blind intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the portion of the lane that will bring you into other drivers' fields of vision at the earliest possible moment.
questions.answerB: Always be in the left lane to be the farthest from oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Slowly sneak up to the intersection.
questions.answerD: Weave slightly in your lane so your headlight has a better chance of being spotted.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection, move into the part of the lane that will bring you into an oncoming driver's field of vision at the earliest possible moment. For example, when approaching a blind corner to your right, you may be seen sooner if you are in the left portion of your lane and not in the center portion.

questions.question: Shifting to a lower gear produces an effect similar to:
questions.answerB: Braking.
questions.answerC: Swerving.
questions.answerD: Turning.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycles have a manual transmission. Downshifting to a lower gear will slow you down.

questions.question: If you are riding in the right side of your lane while following a car:
questions.answerA: You are likely riding in the best position to be seen.
questions.answerB: You may not be seen unless the driver uses their side mirror.
questions.answerC: The driver will most likely assume you are there.
questions.answerD: You are discouraging other drivers from sharing your lane.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a passenger vehicle, it is usually best to ride in the center of the lane so you will be visible in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors, so this lane position will increase your chances of being seen.

questions.question: The faster you drink:
questions.answerA: The more the alcohol will accumulate in your body.
questions.answerB: The faster the alcohol is removed from your body.
questions.answerC: The more minimal the effects of the alcohol will be.
questions.answerD: The more likely you will be able to evade being pulled over.
questions.explanation: The faster you drink, the more alcohol will accumulate in your body. It is never safe to operate a motor vehicle after drinking alcohol in any amount.

questions.question: When stopped behind another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close as possible to the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Maintain a space cushion between your motorcycle and the other vehicle.
questions.answerC: Not use your rearview mirrors to monitor traffic behind you.
questions.answerD: Look for opportunities to squeeze through the stopped traffic.
questions.explanation: You should stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even when you are both stopped. This will give you room to escape if the vehicle backs up unexpectedly or if another vehicle approaches too quickly from behind.

questions.question: How is the accelerator controlled?
questions.answerB: With the left hand
questions.answerC: With the right foot
questions.answerD: With the left foot
questions.explanation: The accelerator of a motorcycle is located by the right handgrip and is controlled with the right hand.

questions.question: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should:
questions.answerB: Avoid making any sudden changes in speed or direction.
questions.answerC: Use only the front brake when stopping.
questions.answerD: Use only the rear brake when stopping.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should reduce your speed. Make certain to use both brakes when braking and avoid making sudden changes in speed or direction.

questions.question: When it comes to motorcycle safety, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume everything on your motorcycle will work properly.
questions.answerB: Conduct a pre-ride inspection before every ride.
questions.answerC: Conduct a pre-ride inspection each month.
questions.answerD: Conduct a pre-ride inspection twice a week.
questions.explanation: A small mechanical fault can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle than on a car. Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle before every ride.

questions.question: When deciding on a lane position, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Always ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Be flexible and base your decision off of numerous factors.
questions.explanation: In general, there is no single best lane position. No portion of the lane need be avoided at all times. Position yourself in the portion of the lane where you are most likely to be seen and you can maintain a cushion of space around you.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to wobble, it is best to:
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Gradually apply your brakes.
questions.explanation: Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble because doing so will only make the motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down by gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as possible, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Avoid applying the brakes, as this may also worsen the wobble.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of protective riding gear?
questions.answerB: Boots that go above the ankle
questions.answerC: Hearing protection
questions.answerD: Pants made of a soft material
questions.explanation: Appropriate protective gear for motorcycling includes a jacket and pants made of leather or another sturdy material; footwear that covers and supports your ankles; and hearing protection, even if you wear a helmet.

questions.question: Which of the following is a poor reason to sound your horn?
questions.answerA: A driver in the lane next to you is too close to the vehicle ahead of them.
questions.answerB: A parked car has a person in the driver’s seat.
questions.answerC: You want people to look at your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: You are passing someone who is in the street.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to sound your horn before riding past a vehicle or pedestrian that may move into your lane. If you see a driver in an adjacent lane driving too closely to the vehicle ahead of them, you may assume that they want to pass and may cut in front of you to do so. If you see a person in the driver's seat of a parked car, or if you see a pedestrian or bicyclist in the street, it is a good idea to sound your horn as you pass.

questions.question: A driver making eye contact with you:
questions.answerB: Will never happen.
questions.answerC: Does not mean that they will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Guarantees that they will properly yield to you.
questions.explanation: You should never count on eye contact to guarantee that a driver will yield to you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist but fail to consciously notice them.

questions.question: Signals on a motorcycle:
questions.answerB: Are even more important than signals on larger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Should not be used unless another vehicle is right next to the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Are less important than signals on larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: Because motorcyclists are more vulnerable than the drivers of cars and trucks, appropriate use of signals by motorcyclists is even more important than it is for other drivers.

questions.question: To help other drivers see you, you should wear:
questions.answerB: Brightly-colored clothes.
questions.answerC: Lights.
questions.answerD: A black jacket.
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored clothing will help you to be seen by other road users. Wear clothes that increase your visibility both during the day and at night.

questions.question: Passing and being passed when riding a motorcycle is not much different than when driving a car. However:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle's visibility is more critical than that of a car.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle's visibility is not as important as that of a car.
questions.answerC: Passing should be done on the shoulder instead of on the main roadway.
questions.answerD: It is critical to make eye contact with the other driver when riding a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: While the basic techniques for safely passing and being passed are the same as when driving a car, visibility is more critical when riding a motorcycle. The smaller size of a motorcycle makes it easier for you to disappear into another vehicle's blind spot, or for the driver to fail to notice you even if they are able to see you.

questions.question: In general, the body gets rid of almost ______ per hour.
questions.answerB: Two drinks
questions.answerC: Three drinks
questions.answerD: Four drinks
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour.

questions.question: When selecting footwear, you should choose:
questions.answerB: Shoes with long laces that cannot be tucked in.
questions.answerC: Shoes that cover your ankles.
questions.answerD: Shoes that are made from flimsy materials.
questions.explanation: When riding, wear boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Heels should be short so they don't catch on rough surfaces. Laces should be tucked in so they can't catch onto the moving parts of the motorcycle.

questions.question: The front brake supplies how much of a motorcycle's potential stopping power?
questions.answerB: About 50 percent
questions.answerC: About 70 percent
questions.answerD: 100 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake and can provide at least 70 percent of the motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: An integrated braking system:
questions.answerA: Applies partial rear braking when the front brake is applied.
questions.answerB: Applies partial front braking when the rear brake is applied.
questions.answerC: Applies even braking for both the front and rear brakes when either is applied.
questions.answerD: Learns and remembers the approximate braking force used by the rider.
questions.explanation: An integrated braking system is a variant of a linked braking system. Partial front braking is applied whenever the rear brake is activated. Check your owner's manual for a detailed explanation of the braking system on your motorcycle.

questions.question: The best way to stop quickly is to:
questions.answerB: Use the front brake first.
questions.answerC: Throttle down and use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: If you need to stop quickly, apply both the front and rear brakes at the same time.

questions.question: The best way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Use your horn and make obscene gestures.
questions.answerC: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: If possible, change lanes and let a tailgater pass your vehicle. Speeding up may result in the driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed, thereby increasing the danger.

questions.question: If the throttle is stuck, you should:
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Twist the throttle back and forth several times.
questions.answerD: Not try to twist the throttle.
questions.explanation: If your throttle becomes stuck, try twisting it back and forth several times. If this does not free your throttle, immediately operate the engine cut-off switch and pull in the clutch at the same time.

questions.question: If someone is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerB: Alert the local police.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder of the road.
questions.answerD: Allow them to pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to let them get in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let the tailgater pass. Riding faster may only increase the danger by prompting them to continue tailgating you at the higher speed.

questions.question: How often must a motorcycle pass a safety inspection?
questions.answerB: Once every two years
questions.answerC: Once every four years
questions.answerD: Once every five years
questions.explanation: Every vehicle registered in the state of Utah, including motorcycles, must pass an annual safety inspection. In addition to a safety inspection, some areas in the state also require an emission test.

questions.question: When you park a motorcycle next to a curb, it should be:
questions.answerA: Parked at a 90-degree angle with the rear wheel touching the curb.
questions.answerB: Parked at a 45-degree angle with the front tire touching the curb.
questions.answerC: Parked like a car, with the front and rear wheels the same distance from the curb.
questions.answerD: Parked at the left edge of the parking space so approaching drivers can more easily see the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: When parking a motorcycle next to a curb, you should create at a 90-degree angle with the curb by touching your rear wheel to the curb.

questions.question: Low-speed crashes:
questions.answerB: Are never serious.
questions.answerC: Rarely cause injuries.
questions.answerD: Happen frequently, so there is no need to worry about them.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes occur at speeds lower than 30 miles per hour. Even low-speed crashes can be fatal.

questions.question: You can increase your visibility by:
questions.answerA: Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Not using your turn signal.
questions.answerC: Wearing dark clothing.
questions.answerD: Waving at people.
questions.explanation: To increase your visibility, you can wear clothing that is brightly-colored or that contains reflective materials. Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle, using your turn signals, and flashing your brake light when appropriate are also good ways to get the attention of other road users.

questions.question: Where should a load be placed?
questions.answerB: As high as possible
questions.answerC: Behind the rear axle
questions.answerD: On one side of the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Loads should kept low, either fastened securely or in saddlebags. Piling loads against a sissy bar or frame on the back of a seat is dangerous because it can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and change the balance of the motorcycle. Loads should be equally distributed on both sides of the motorcycle.

questions.question: A motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Pick a favorite portion of the lane and stay in that portion all the time.
questions.answerB: Continually weave among the lane positions to keep other drivers out of their lane.
questions.answerC: Choose a lane position based on road and traffic conditions.
questions.answerD: Not worry about lane position.
questions.explanation: There is no one lane position that is always best and no one lane position that should always be avoided. Adjust your lane position in response to changes in road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: If you are transporting a passenger, they should:
questions.answerB: Hold onto the motorcycle seat.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto you.
questions.explanation: A passenger should lean with the operator through turns and curves. They should sit as far forward as possible, without hindering the operator's control of the motorcycle, and hold onto passenger handholds or the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good way for a rider to increase their visibility?
questions.answerB: Using their headlight at all times
questions.answerC: Using their turn signals
questions.answerD: Waving at other drivers
questions.explanation: To make yourself visible to other road users, you should wear brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials, use your headlight at all times, and use your signals and brake light properly.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat while you are riding and you must stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both brakes and stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good tire.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good tire and steer to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Relax on the handgrips.
questions.explanation: If either of your tires go flat while you are riding, hold the handgrips firmly, ease off the throttle, and maintain a straight course.
